articles.headline: Secret Life of a Deal
articles.snippet: Two of Dow Chemical’s top executives worked on a $50 billion takeover of their company last year, behind the backs of the company’s chief executive and board.
articles.abstract: Two of Dow Chemical’s top executives worked on a $50 billion takeover of their company last year, behind the backs of the company’s chief executive and board.

articles.headline: Grasso’s Grit May Win After All
articles.snippet: The chances are growing that Richard A. Grasso will keep the $185 million pay package that led to his ouster as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.abstract: The chances are growing that Richard A. Grasso will keep the $185 million pay package that led to his ouster as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call it the curse of Dick Grasso.

articles.headline: Mr. Bill Returns (in One Piece) to Pitch a Debit Card
articles.snippet: Mr. Bill, the clay doll that was pulverized in vintage “Saturday Night Live” skits, makes it through the day in a new ad campaign by MasterCard.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bill, the clay doll that was pulverized in vintage “Saturday Night Live” skits, makes it through the day in a new ad campaign by MasterCard.
articles.lead_paragraph: MasterCard executives have found a new poster boy for the angst-ridden economy: Mr. Bill.

articles.headline: Chavez Decree Tightens Hold on Intelligence
articles.snippet: Sweeping changes to Venezuela’s intelligence agencies have provoked concerns that citizens will be forced to inform on one another to avoid prison.
articles.abstract: Sweeping changes to Venezuela’s intelligence agencies have provoked concerns that citizens will be forced to inform on one another to avoid prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez has used his decree powers to carry out a major overhaul of this country’s intelligence agencies, provoking a fierce backlash here from human rights groups and legal scholars who say the measures will force citizens to inform on one another to avoid prison terms.

articles.headline: Obama Pushes Effort to Claim Victory Tonight
articles.snippet: Barack Obama was wooing superdelegates as Hillary Rodham Clinton prepared what aides described as a farewell speech to sum up the case for her candidacy.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama was wooing superdelegates as Hillary Rodham Clinton prepared what aides described as a farewell speech to sum up the case for her candidacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Adam Nagourney, Carl Hulse and Jeff Zeleny and written by Mr. Nagourney.

articles.headline: Wachovia Forces Out Its Chief
articles.snippet: The ouster of G. Kennedy Thompson as chief executive, announced Monday morning, leaves the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank confronting an uncertain future.
articles.abstract: The ouster of G. Kennedy Thompson as chief executive, announced Monday morning, leaves the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank confronting an uncertain future.
articles.lead_paragraph: G. Kennedy Thompson spent 32 years building the Wachovia Corporation into one of the nation’s biggest banks. But late last Thursday, as problems at Wachovia continued to worsen, the company’s chairman gave Mr. Thompson the bad news: his career at the bank was over.

articles.headline: It Isn’t Magic: Putin Opponents Vanish From TV
articles.snippet: Critics of the government, and of Vladimir V. Putin, have been placed on a roster of individuals barred from TV news and talk shows.
articles.abstract: Critics of the government, and of Vladimir V. Putin, have been placed on a roster of individuals barred from TV news and talk shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  On a talk show last fall, a prominent political analyst named Mikhail G. Delyagin had some tart words about Vladimir V. Putin. When the program was later televised, Mr. Delyagin was not.

articles.headline: Commodity Regulators Vow Stricter Oversight
articles.snippet: The regulators will look more closely at investors to determine whether they are evading market limits on speculation and artificially driving up world food prices.
articles.abstract: The regulators will look more closely at investors to determine whether they are evading market limits on speculation and artificially driving up world food prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators of the nation’s commodity markets will demand more information about investors to determine whether they are evading market limits on speculation and artificially driving up world food prices.
